data.title: Fraunces Tavern Museum
data.meta_description: Spread the loveCLASS Originally built in 1719, the Fraunces Tavern was the site of George Washington’s farewell dinner to his troops following the American Revolution. Interpret paintings of the war and the stories they tell, and see colonial history exhibits. 54 Pearl Street, New York, NY 10004. 212-425-1778. Fee. This tavern was an important meeting […]
data.text:
Historic Site Lesson Plan

FUN FACTS

Philadelphia’s Independence Hall, where the Declaration of Independence and Constitution were signed; Boston’s Old State House, where the Boston Massacre and the American Revolution began; Washington D.C.’s National Mall, where Martin Luther King, Jr. delivered his “I Have a Dream” speech; Virginia’s Jamestown settlement, the country’s first colony; Charleston’s Fort Sumter, where the first shots of the Civil War were fired; New York’s Statue of Liberty and Ellis Island, where millions of immigrants were introduced to their new home. All of these sites, significant to America’s history, can be visited, toured, and admired. While visiting one of the many historical sites around the country, consider the importance in preserving these sites.

View Lesson Plan>>
